summary: A letter from the Marsh Law Firm, representing survivors of Jeffrey Epstein, to the FBI Director, DOJ Inspector General, and Attorney General. It details the FBI's failure to investigate Epstein's sex trafficking and possible child sexual abuse material (CSAM) crimes, citing a client's 1996 report and subsequent inaction. It calls for a comprehensive investigation into these failures. This document is a stipulated motion and subsequent court order from the civil case USVI v. JPMorgan Chase. It establishes a protocol for the Epstein Estate to review video and photo materials (Epstein Media) for child sex abuse material (CSAM) before producing responsive items to Jane Doe 1 and other parties, with a requirement to notify the FBI if potential CSAM is found.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell

connections.description: Accused of jointly sexually abusing a client in Ohio in 1996 and participating in a sex trafficking conspiracy.
Business partners at Towers Financial; Hoffenberg was prosecuted for fraud while Epstein was not.
Epstein had three meetings scheduled with Burns in 2014, indicating a connection to high-level government officials.
Freeman, as counsel for survivors, is advocating for investigation into Epstein's crimes and the FBI's failures.
Jane Doe 1 alleges she was a victim of coerced commercial sex trafficking by Jeffrey Epstein and his co-conspirators.
Staley is the third-party defendant sued by JPMorgan Chase in the same case.
Bradley Edwards is listed as counsel for plaintiff Jane Doe 1.

connections.description: Linda Singer is counsel for the plaintiff Government of the United States Virgin Islands.
John Butts is counsel for defendant JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A.
Zachary K. Warren is counsel for third-party defendant James Edward Staley.

events.title: Client's Report to NYPD and FBI
events.description: A client reported to the NYPD and then the FBI that Epstein and Maxwell sexually abused her and were involved in sex trafficking and possible CSAM crimes.

events.title: Raid on Epstein's Palm Beach Home
events.description: Police raided Epstein's Palm Beach home, finding 'naked pictures of teenage girls' and child erotica.

events.title: FBI Meeting with Client
events.description: FBI agents met with the client in North Carolina, acknowledging her 1996 report and discussing her concerns about Epstein's sex trafficking and CSAM allegations.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA)
events.description: The federal government entered into a secret non-prosecution agreement with Epstein, requiring only minor state pleas and immunizing co-conspirators.

events.title: Epstein Charged and Mansion Searched
events.description: Epstein was charged with sex trafficking, and a search of his New York mansion found a 'vast trove' of lewd photographs of young-looking girls in a safe.

events.title: Estate Discovers New Media
events.description: The Epstein Estate discovered new videos and photographs (Epstein Media) and expressed concern some might contain CSAM, leading to a court-ordered review protocol.

events.title: Estate Notifies of Found Media
events.description: Counsel for the Epstein Estate notified Jane Doe 1's counsel that it had located materials within the Epstein Media that may be responsive to her subpoenas and expressed concern some might contain CSAM.

events.title: Filing of Stipulated Motion
events.description: Plaintiffs Jane Doe 1 and the Government of the USVI file a stipulated motion for approval of a protocol to review Epstein Media for CSAM.

events.title: Court Order Approving Protocol
events.description: The court issues an order approving the protocol for the Epstein Estate to review video materials and photographs for CSAM and produce responsive media.

locations: United States District Court for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: A client reported Epstein and Maxwell's sex trafficking and possible CSAM crimes to the FBI in August 1996, but the FBI failed to investigate.
In 2005, child erotica and naked pictures of teenage girls were found in Epstein's Palm Beach home; computer hard drives were suspiciously removed before a police raid.
The 2008 non-prosecution agreement allowed Epstein to plead to minor state crimes and immunized co-conspirators, enabling continued trafficking.
In 2019, a 'vast trove' of lewd photographs of young-looking girls was found in a safe in Epstein's New York mansion.
The Epstein Estate discovered new media in March 2023 and alerted the court it might contain CSAM, prompting a federal review protocol.
The Epstein Estate possesses a collection of video and photo materials ('Epstein Media') that is subject to subpoenas in civil litigation.
There is a specific concern that the Epstein Media may contain child sex abuse material (CSAM), prompting the need for a court-approved review protocol.
The established protocol requires the Estate to stop review and notify the FBI immediately if potential CSAM is observed, to avoid legal liability.
The case involves Jane Doe 1, who alleges she was a victim of sex trafficking by Jeffrey Epstein and his co-conspirators.
The document is a joint motion agreed to by all parties, including the Epstein Estate, Jane Doe 1, the USVI Government, JPMorgan Chase, and James Staley.
